text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
IRM 5.17.13.3 - added note discussing case in which the holding in Romani was not applied because the IRS was not relying on a claim for which a tax lien arose.

IRM 5.17.13.6 - revised to clarify the IRS may, in its discretion, allow payment of administrative expenses unless the amounts are excessive or unreasonable. References that the IRS should concede expenses have been removed. Also added cross references to applicable provisions in IRM 5.5.2, Probate Proceedings and the State Law Guides on the My SB/SE Counsel website.

IRM 5.17.13.7 - added references to IRM procedures for filing proofs of claim in non-bankruptcy insolvency proceedings and probate proceedings; revised discussion of advantages and disadvantages for filing proofs of claim; added note regarding importance of timely removing state court proceedings to federal district court; and added references to newly revised IRM 5.5.4, Proof Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases.

IRM 5.17.13.8(6) - clarified that as a requirement to impose personal liability, the Government must show that the fiduciary had either actual knowledge of the tax liability or knowledge of such facts as would put a reasonably prudent person on notice as to the existence of the tax debt before making the challenged distribution or payment. Added new (7) to address sending notice to successor administrator.

IRM 5.17.13.10.3 - revised to clarify that the Federal Priority Statute, 31 USC § 3713(a), applies when the assets of a decedent’s estate in the custody of the executor or administrator are not enough to pay all debts of the decedent; and that the assets of the estate will include any claims the executor has against holders of property that can be used to pay the tax liability.
IRM 5.17.13.12.1 - clarifies that an assignee for the benefit of creditors is subject to the federal tax lien even though a Notice of Federal Tax Lien has not been filed.

Editorial changes were made throughout this section to add or update cross-references to applicable IRM provisions, to clarify provisions by revising or removing confusing, redundant or outdated information, and to update or correct citations.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS This supersedes IRM 5.17.13 dated October 16, 2007.

(07-09-2012) Priority of Government Claims Under 31 USC § 3713(a), the Federal Priority Statute
Section

)(B) of the Federal Priority Statute covers decedents’ estates. The Federal Government is entitled to have its claims paid first if the estate of the deceased debtor, in the custody of the executor or administrator, is not enough to pay all debts of the debtor. This means, among other things, that the Government is entitled to be paid before the heirs receive an inheritance.

Section 3713(a)(1)(B) of the Federal Priority Statute covers decedents’ estates. The Federal Government is entitled to have its claims paid first if the estate of the deceased debtor, in the custody of the executor or administrator, is not enough to pay all debts of the debtor. This means, among other things, that the Government is entitled to be paid before the heirs receive an inheritance.

) Under the definition, an act of bankruptcy may arise even when there has been no transfer of property to a fiduciary, and multiple acts of bankruptcy exist in one transfer. In United States v. Golden Acres, Inc.,
F.Supp.
Del.
), an insolvent corporation owing a debt to the United States paid $

to its sole officers and directors. In doing so it committed three independent acts of bankruptcy: it made a preferential transfer of assets to sole officers and directors; it conveyed property with the intent to hinder, or defraud any creditor, which was a fraudulent conveyance; and it property without receiving fair consideration, which also was a fraudulent veyance. The district court imposed liability on the payees/officers under section
(b) because they were representatives of Golden Acres and “liable to the extent of the payment for unpaid claims of the government.” (
) In a lawsuit asserting an act of bankruptcy, care must be taken to ensure all of the elements for a particular act of bankruptcy are proven. For in Jonathan’s Landing, Inc. v. Townsend,
F.
d
th Cir.

), the district court granted the Government’s motion for summary judgment, which asserted that the third act of bankruptcy applied to the debtor: the debtor suffered or permitted, while insolvent, any creditor to obtain a lien upon any his property through legal proceedings or distraint. The Eleventh Circuit reversed the district court, reasoning that summary judgment should not been granted because the Government had failed to prove that the debtor had been insolvent prior to committing an act of bankruptcy. arran-Ferguson Act (
USC §
et seq.). The M

arran-Ferguson Act provides that no federal can supersede any state law regulating the insurance business. In Fabe, the Federal Priority Statute did not trump state law that subordinated federal tax claims to insurance claims of policyholders in the liquidation of an insolvent insurance company. (

) The Service may, in limited circumstances, cede priority for purposes of funding claims for family allowances, funeral expenses, or administrative expenses, even though debts to the Government technically have priority these claims. Note: The Federal Priority Statute does not apply in bankruptcy cases (i.e., bank- ruptcy petitions filed under Title
) Although the Federal Priority Statute,
USC §

, does not provide for exceptions to the Government’s priority, courts have held that certain classes of claim can be paid before the tax debt. These excepted classes include ad- ministrative expenses, funeral expenses, and homestead or family (
) Administrative expenses are expenses incurred for the general welfare of creditors. Administrative expenses include: (cid:
) court costs (cid:
) reasonable compensation for the fiduciary and fiduciary’s attorney (cid:
) expenses incurred to collect and preserve assets (
) Administrative expenses must be examined to determine if the expense is sonable and necessary to the administration of the estate. For more information, see IRM
, Administrative Expenses. See also IRM

, Necessary Administrative Expenses for factors to consider when determining what expenses should be allowed as necessary administrative expenses. For example, reasonable and necessary expenses should not be permitted ahead of a tax lien if such expenses are already covered by an insurance policy, trust or other similar benefit that covers such costs. See
, Insurance Policies. (

) Generally, state statutes provide limits on the amounts allowed for payment reasonable administrative expenses. Some state law guidelines are based on the size of the estate, other provisions allow a set percentage to be paid as allowable expense. Some expenses can be negotiated to a certain extent by the estate administrator, others, such as court filing fees, are not negotiable. State standards should be considered, but are not controlling, when ing whether administrative expenses are reasonable. See IRM
, Reasonable Administrative Expenses. Information regarding a particular laws may be found in the State Law Guides on the My SB/SE Counsel Internal Revenue Manual
In United States v. Fabe,
U.S.
), the Supreme Court held that the federal priority yields if it interferes with the M
arran-Ferguson Act (
USC §
et seq.). The M

arran-Ferguson Act provides that no federal law can supersede any state law regulating the insurance business. In Fabe, the Federal Priority Statute did not trump state law that subordinated federal tax claims to insurance claims of policyholders in the liquidation of an insolvent insurance company. The Service may, in limited circumstances, cede priority for purposes of funding claims for family allowances, funeral expenses, or administrative expenses, even though debts to the Government technically have priority over

In United States v. Fabe, 508 U.S. 491 (1993), the Supreme Court held that the federal priority yields if it interferes with the McCarran-Ferguson Act (15 USC § 1011 et seq.). The McCarran-Ferguson Act provides that no federal can supersede any state law regulating the insurance business. In Fabe, the Federal Priority Statute did not trump state law that subordinated federal tax claims to insurance claims of policyholders in the liquidation of an insolvent insurance company.
Note: The Federal Priority Statute does not apply in bankruptcy cases (i.e., bank- ruptcy petitions filed under Title 11.

trat/Offices/sbse/Pages/La
uides.aspx. (

) The family allowance is not considered an administrative expense of the estate. In limited circumstances, the Service can exercise discretion to allow payment ahead of a tax lien. Consideration needs to be given to circum- stances such as whether there are minor children who do not have another parent to support them. For example, if the surviving parent has sufficient income, trust distributions or life insurance proceeds to support minor or pacitated children, this payment would not be allowed ahead of the tax lien. Note: A federal tax lien, arising before death, continues in the property to which attached and therefore is prior to funeral costs, the surviving spouse’s exempt property allowance (widow’s allowance) and any support (for the surviving spouse and minor children during administration of the estate). Consult with Area Counsel if you have any questions regarding allowance and payment of such expenses ahead of IRS claims. (
) Fees paid to the fiduciary or the fiduciary’s attorney may be deemed able if: (cid:
) the fees are excessive in amount, or (cid:
) they are incurred in support of unreasonable activity, e.g., positions that frivolous or without substantial merit, (cid:
) or they have been estimated or not incurred. Reasonable attorney fees are those incurred for preserving or marshalling assets. See IRM

), Necessary Administrative Expenses. In ings other than probate proceedings, such as receiverships or dissolutions, the Government may also argue that “reasonable” fees are to fees that benefit the Government as the priority claimant (e.g. fees sell receivership assets or to pursue claims against third parties). (
) The expenses of a decedent’s last illness are a debt of the decedent and entitled to priority under section
Rev. Rul.
C.B.
) Taxes incurred by the estate during its administration should be paid as an ministrative expense of the estate. See IRM

, Claiming Taxes an Administrative Expense. It is less clear whether administrative taxes, incurred during a receivership, are entitled to priority by virtue of the Federal Priority Statute or by virtue of being “administrative” expenses. Consult local Area Counsel if a question involving the priority of administrative taxes (

, Proof of Claim Procedures for procedures for filing proofs of claim in decedent cases. Note: To share in distribution from the probate estate, you must file a timely against the estate, because most probate courts will not consider a debt unless a timely claim is submitted. (

Consideration needs to be given to circum- stances such as whether there are minor children who do not have another parent to support them. For example, if the surviving parent has sufficient income, trust distributions or life insurance proceeds to support minor or inca- pacitated children, this payment would not be allowed ahead of the tax lien. Consult with Area Counsel if you have any questions regarding the allowance and payment of such expenses ahead of IRS claims. (

stances such as whether there are minor children who do not have another parent to support them. For example, if the surviving parent has sufficient income, trust distributions or life insurance proceeds to support minor or inca
pacitated children, this payment would not be allowed ahead of the tax lien.

Reasonable attorney fees are those incurred for preserving or marshalling estate assets. See IRM 5.5.2.6.1.1(1), Necessary Administrative Expenses. In proceed- ings other than probate proceedings, such as receiverships or corporate dissolutions, the Government may also argue that “reasonable” fees are limited to fees that benefit the Government as the priority claimant (e.g. fees incurred to sell receivership assets or to pursue claims against third parties).
The expenses of a decedent’s last illness are a debt of the decedent and not entitled to priority under section 3713. Rev. Rul. 80-112, 1980-1 C.B. 306.
The IRS may file a proof of claim to collect any tax liability from the assets in a judicial insolvency proceeding. See IRM
, Non-Bankruptcy Insolvencies, for procedures for filing claims in certain types of non-bankruptcy insolvency proceedings. See IRM
, Proof of Claim Procedures for procedures for filing proofs of claim in decedent cases.

5.17.13.8 (07-09-2012) Asserting Personal Liability Against a Fiduciary
A decedent’s estate, or probate proceeding, is governed by state law. The purpose of the proceeding is to gather and distribute the decedent’s
The assets administered in the probate proceeding are part of the dece

dent’s estate. These consist of assets that the decedent owned prior to decedent’s death. A personal representative or administrator is appointed by the probate court to administer the assets of the estate. The personal representative’s duties include a) gathering the assets of the deceased; b) paying the ad
ministrative expenses, taxes and other debts of the deceased; c) distributing the remaining assets as specified in the will or state law.

Legal Reference Guide for Revenue c. The decedent may have executed (signed) a will or died intestate a will). If the decedent has executed a will, the executor named in the is appointed as personal representative. If the named executor is deceased or declines to act (and the will does not name a successor is willing to serve as executor), or if no will has been executed, then court will appoint an administrator as personal representative. d. Some assets are not subject to probate administration including a) property held jointly with the right of survivorship; b) proceeds from life insurance policies; and c) property transferred to a trust during the dent’s life. Such assets may transfer at death directly to the survivor without going through probate. In such a case, these assets will not be within the custody of the court. e. The probate proceeding may be court supervised or may be an proceeding not requiring court supervision. If the proceeding is court pervised, the personal representative must obtain court approval to many actions such as distributing assets. (

) Usually the IRS will assert a tax claim against an estate by filing a proof of claim in any judicially supervised probate proceeding. This is because the cedent’s probate estate is under the jurisdiction of the state court. Notice of tax liability should be given to the personal representative to ensure that the representative will be subject to
USC §
(b) personal liability. (

) State laws typically direct that the fiduciary must distribute estate assets in following order of priority: a. costs and expenses of administration (including homestead and family lowances) b. reasonable funeral expenses c. debts and taxes with preference under federal law d. expenses of the decedent’s last illness e. debts and taxes with preference under state law f. all other claims (
) However, insofar as state priority laws conflict with the federal priority, the federal priority controls. (
) A statutory lien that arises against property of a taxpayer before a death continues to attach to the property after the taxpayer’s death. United States v. Bess,
U.S.

State courts have jurisdiction over a decedents’ estate. Usually, state statutes designate a particular court to supervise the administration of estates. These courts are often known as probate courts. A decedent’s estate is generally ad
ministered in the probate court of the county in which the decedent resided at the time of death.
Note: Many of the State Law Guides on the My SB/SE Counsel website include discussion of applicable state law regarding probate proceedings. http://
Many of the State Law Guides on the My SB/SE Counsel website include a discussion of applicable state law regarding probate proceedings. http:// ccintranet.prod.irscounsel.treas.gov/Or
trat/Offices/sbse/Pages/La

uides.aspx. Generally, the first step in the judicial probate of a will is to file the will with probate court. After a party proves a will to be genuine, the court will issue letters of administration to an executor. The executor then has the duty of gathering together and inventorying the estate assets, paying the debts of the decedent, and making distributions of the assets. If there is no will, a party may file a petition with the probate court to request that the court appoint an administrator. The court will issue letters of adminis- tration and charge an administrator to perform the same tasks as the Both the executor and the administrator are known as personal representa- tives. The personal representative may be required to post a bond before appointment to act for the estate.
Legal Reference Guide for Revenue (

) Creditors, including the IRS, can file claims against the estate. The personal representative will approve or disapprove each claim. If the fiduciary disap- proves the claim, then the creditor may argue the case before the probate court. The creditor may also appeal an adverse decision to a state appellate court. After all disputes are settled, the personal representative distributes assets. Heirs and devisees get any remaining assets after creditor’s claims satisfied. (
) Section
(a) priority applies to a decedent’s estate when the assets of estate in the custody of the executor or administrator are not enough to pay of debts of the decedent. (

) Assets of the estate do not include certain property passing outside of such as jointly held property. However, the estate does include any claims executor has against holders of property that can be used to pay the tax liability. For example, under IRC §
and
, the executor has the right to compel contributions toward the estate tax from life insurance recipients property subject to a power of appointment. (

USC §
(a) priority applies, then the personal representative be liable under

(b) for distributions that violate federal priority. (

) A receivership usually has one of two purposes: a. A receivership can be a secondary proceeding brought to protect until a primary legal proceeding is completed. For example, a mortgagee in a mortgage foreclosure suit may ask for the appointment of a receiver to take custody of the specific property subject to the mortgage, such as hotel or other commercial property that is producing income. The must collect the rents and operate the property during the foreclosure ceeding. This might preserve the value of the property pending the foreclosure sale. b. A receiver can also be appointed to liquidate all of the debtor’s assets to pay the debtor’s debts. A receivership is an alternative to an for the benefit of creditors and a bankruptcy proceeding. (

) A receivership can be a: a. general receivership in which the receiver takes control of all assets of debtor, or b. a limited receivership in which specific assets are in the custody of the receiver. Ordinarily a limited receivership is for the benefit of specific creditors (e.g., a mortgage foreclosure). (
) A receivership, especially a limited receivership, does not always involve an insolvent debtor. (

) Generally, an interested party may initiate a receivership by filing a motion seeks to have a receiver appointed by the court. A receivership can be a secondary proceeding brought to protect property until a primary legal proceeding is completed. For example, a mortgagee in a mortgage foreclosure suit may ask for the appointment of a receiver to take custody of the specific property subject to the mortgage, such as a hotel or other commercial property that is producing income. The receiver must collect the rents and operate the property during the foreclosure pro- ceeding. This might preserve the value of the property pending the foreclosure sale. b. A receivership is an alternative to an for the benefit of creditors and a bankruptcy proceeding. A receivership can be a: a. general receivership in which the receiver takes control of all assets of the debtor, or b. a limited receivership in which specific assets are in the custody of the receiver. ) Creditors might want to initiate a receivership if a debtor is on the border between successful business operations and failure. The creditors might that a receiver will be able to operate profitably to make the business In such a case, the receiver will take charge of the property of the debtor manage it for a period of time. The goal is to earn an amount sufficient to the creditors. If this cannot be done, the receiver may, with court permission, liquidate as much of the property as is necessary to pay the debts. The receiver can then distribute the proceeds to the creditors and return the balance, if any, to the debtor. (
) A majority of receivership actions arise in the state courts because the basis for federal district court jurisdiction is limited. (

) An assignment for the benefit of creditors is a state law proceeding in which the debtor voluntarily transfers his property to another party (the assignee) in trust. The assignee then uses or sells the property to pay the debtor’s debts. (
) The assignment can be a general assignment of all or substantially all of the debtor’s property or a partial assignment of only some of the debtor’s (

Also, the IRS may not levy. Accordingly, the statute suspends the collection period of tions while the property of a general assignment is under the control or custody of the court. IRC §

under the assignment to share in the distribution of the assigned property. Normally, the assignee takes title to the assigned property as a trustee, and in general the assignee’s duties, powers, and liabilities are those of a fiduciary.

Normally, the assignee takes title to the assigned property as a trustee, and general the assignee’s duties, powers, and liabilities are those of a fiduciary. The assignee takes the assigned property subject to all liens and encum- brances. Some states have enacted statutes prohibiting an assignor from preferring or more creditors over other creditors in making an assignment for the of creditors. Under these statutes, the assignment must be for the equal benefit of all the assignor’s creditors. Like a receivership, the assignment differs from a bankruptcy case in that debtor does not receive a discharge of debts. Like a receiver, an assignee for the benefit of creditors does not fall within of the protected categories of IRC §

Therefore, the assignee is to the federal tax lien even though a Notice of Federal Tax Lien has not filed. If the tax liability is assessed before the assignment, a valid tax lien exists against all the assignor’s property. The effect of the assignee taking property is that the Government retains its interest in the property to the of its lien and the Government is entitled to enforce its lien against the property.

) A corporation is considered a “person.” A corporation exists separately from identity of its stockholders and officers. a. This means that the corporation itself can own property, can sue and be sued, and can incur tax liability. b. It also means that this separate existence may come to an end. When corporation’s existence does end, the corporate affairs are wound up (the corporation must pay its debts and distribute its remaining assets). This process is a “corporate dissolution.”

) A corporation’s existence is artificial, created by state law. State statutes provide for: a. the creation of the corporation; b. the period of its existence; and c. termination of its life. (
) Stockholders of a corporation may decide to terminate the corporate They may voluntarily dissolve the corporation and forfeit the corporate (

) The state may also initiate a proceeding to forfeit the corporate charter. a state will do this as a method of enforcing some state law requirement. most common example of this is the state requirement that corporations pay state franchise tax. If the required payment is not made, the state may bring an action to forfeit the charter, thereby terminating the corporate existence. (

) If difficulties arise in the liquidation of assets, payment of claims, or of assets, or if state law requires, dissolution may be conducted in a court ceeding. a. Usually the court appoints a receiver, liquidator, or other fiduciary. The fiduciary must attend to the dissolution under orders of the court and the court will hear and determine all controversies that arise during the of the dissolution. b. The IRS should file a claim in such a proceeding to collect from the of the corporation. c. The IRS cannot levy on any property within the custody of the court. d. A bankruptcy corporate liquidation differs from a non-bankruptcy judicial liquidation in that the bankruptcy proceeding is governed by bankruptcy law and is supervised by a federal court, while the non- bankruptcy judicial proceeding is governed by state corporate law and is supervised by a state court. (

) If the parties are able to liquidate the corporation without the help of a court and if all parties and creditors are satisfied that justice is being done, there no reason for court action. The parties may conduct the liquidation entirely of court if state law permits. a. A nonjudicial liquidation is likely if there is either enough money to pay corporate creditors or if the value and disposition of the assets and the priority among claimants is not disputed. b. A nonjudicial dissolution is usually conducted by the officers of the ration. Such officers become trustees for creditors and act in a fiduciary capacity. c. If at any time during a nonjudicial dissolution the Government that the interests of the United States are not protected, then the ment may bring suit to subject corporate properties to payment of tax under IRC §
The Government can seek to appoint a receiver IRC §
(d). Such action converts the nonjudicial dissolution into a judicial dissolution. d. The Government may also consider administrative collection action in judicial dissolutions.
5.17 Legal Reference Guide for Revenue
(2) A corporation’s existence is artificial, created by state law. State statutes
Stockholders of a corporation may decide to terminate the corporate existence. They may voluntarily dissolve the corporation and forfeit the corporate charter.

The state may also initiate a proceeding to forfeit the corporate charter. Usually a state will do this as a method of enforcing some state law requirement. The most common example of this is the state requirement that corporations pay a state franchise tax. If the required payment is not made, the state may bring an action to forfeit the charter, thereby terminating the corporate existence.
If difficulties arise in the liquidation of assets, payment of claims, or distribution of assets, or if state law requires, dissolution may be conducted in a court pro-

of assets, or if state law requires, dissolution may be conducted in a court ceeding. a. Usually the court appoints a receiver, liquidator, or other fiduciary. The fiduciary must attend to the dissolution under orders of the court and the court will hear and determine all controversies that arise during the of the dissolution. b. The IRS should file a claim in such a proceeding to collect from the of the corporation. c. The IRS cannot levy on any property within the custody of the court. d. A bankruptcy corporate liquidation differs from a non-bankruptcy judicial liquidation in that the bankruptcy proceeding is governed by bankruptcy law and is supervised by a federal court, while the non- bankruptcy judicial proceeding is governed by state corporate law and is supervised by a state court. If the parties are able to liquidate the corporation without the help of a court and if all parties and creditors are satisfied that justice is being done, there is no reason for court action. The parties may conduct the liquidation entirely of court if state law permits. a. A nonjudicial liquidation is likely if there is either enough money to pay all corporate creditors or if the value and disposition of the assets and the priority among claimants is not disputed. b. The Government can seek to appoint a receiver under IRC §
(d). Such action converts the nonjudicial dissolution into a judicial dissolution. d. The Government may also consider administrative collection action in judicial dissolutions.

) The fiduciary who is charged with liquidating the corporation will first collect corporate assets, inventory the assets, value, liquidate them and make of Fiduciaries butions to creditors and stockholders. (

) The fiduciary must ordinarily give notice of the dissolution to all who might claims against the corporation. This will usually be a public notice such as newspaper publication in addition to specific notice to each known creditor required by state law. The notice will give the place where claims are to be filed and the date by which they should be filed. (

) If money or property remains in the hands of the liquidator after satisfaction claims against the corporation, the balance will be distributed to the ers. All valid claims against the corporation must be paid before anything is distributed to stockholders, but after payment of claims all equity remaining the corporation belongs to the stockholders. (
) Priority of the United States versus other creditors of the corporation will be determined by IRC §

In the event of a corporate merger or consolidation, the successor corporation often takes all the assets and assumes all the liabilities of the old corporation. Collection from the successor corporation can be effected by the same means as discussed with respect to stockholders.

Corporate mergers or consolidations can take many forms. Before attempting to collect from a successor corporation, contact the successor corporation to obtain documents describing the transaction and consult with Chief Counsel.

) An offer in compromise may be considered when it is unlikely that the tax liability can be collected in full and the amount offered reasonably reflects lection potential.
